STATE TKEAMKER'S REPORT. TREASURY DEPARTMENT, STATE OF NEBRASKA, Lincoln, December 1, 1916. To His Excellency The Governor of Nebraska, and The 35th Session of the Legislature. rs Persuant to the requirements of the Constitution and the Laws of this State, I herewith respectfully submit my biennial report of the State Treasury for the biennium ending November 30th, 1916. At the beginning of the biennium, December 1st, 1914, there was a warrant indebtedness bearing four per cent interest against the State, which was represented by registered warrants, as shown in the follow- ing statement: This indebtedness has been paid out of the receipts of the Treasury during the past biennium in addition to the payment of all the regular ex - penses of the government for the biennium. At the present time the State has no public debt either in bonds, notes or warrants. At the beginning of the biennium, there was a total balance in the several funds of the Treasury in the amount of $746,108.92, and at the close of the biennium. there was left in the several funds of the Treasury $1,288,674.39, which shows an increase of cash in the Treasury in the amount of $542,565.47. This increase, together with the payment of the warrant c"ebt of the previous biennium, shows a gain for the funds of the department over the expenses of the biennium in the amount of $1,385,- 624.47. It should be. and no doubt is. a matter of pride to all Nebraskans that the State's financial affairs are in such excellent condition, espec - ially when .we look at the fact that the State tax levy for 1915 and 1916 was $1,018,000 lower than it was for 1913 and 1914 and those responsible for this satisfactory condition are entitled to the commendation of the tax payers of the state. At the time I assumed charge and supervision of the Treasury, on January 7. 1915, there was a total warrant Indebtedness of $826,952.3:' General Fund .... f(fU^,OAl/.O. Iniversity Fund Normal Fund .... 140.959.81 149,278.37 Total $843,059.00

4 REPORT OF bearing four per cent interest, and at the same time there were State funds lying in the hands of the County Treasurers in the amount of }1.26y,iRMi. Xo previous State Treasurer had exercised his right to re - quire County Treasurers to pay State funds into the State Treasury more •An than twice a year, as provided in Chapter 69, Section 6507 of the Revised Statutes. of 1913. On February 23, 1815, 1 made the require - ment that every County Treasurer should pay all State funds collected by him during eacli month into the State Treasury on or before the loth of the next or following month. This requirement was supplemented by a 'peremptory writ of mandamus by the Supreme Court; see State Ex Rel George E. Hall, State Treasurer, Relator. v. William G. Ure, Treas - urer of Douglas County, Respondent, 99 Neb. 486. A few of the far - reaching benefits accruing to the officers, employees, creditors and tax - payers of the State are worthy of note. It paid the State warrant debt: stopped the registering of warrants and paying of interest;* turned the money into the State Treasury instead of leaving it spread over the State with the County Treasurers; brought a larger return of interest from money deposited in banks;* saved the State's officers, employees and creditors from the loss of discount on their warrants: permitted the in - vestment funds to be invested in five per cent bonds instead of four per cent warrants; gave back to the common schools of the state unusually large apportionments* from the temporary school fund, and made pos - sible a reduction in the state tax levy for the general fund of $1,018,000. as compared with the previous biennum. Biennium School Apportionments Int. received Int. Paid on on Ilk. Deposits Regis. Warrants During the biennium, there has been paid from the general fund $5,202,439. 55. During the previous biennium, there was paid from the gen - eral fund of the state, $4,690,482.32, which shows an excess for the pres - ent biennium of $511,957.25. When we take into consideration the war - rant indebtedness against the fund at the beginning of the biennium, It shows that the expenses of the state from the genera! fund during the present biennium has been about the same as it was for the previous biennium ; and this would also show that the lowering of the levy for the biennium in the amount of $1,018,000, nearly all of which was for the general fund, was only a means of leaving the money in the pockets of the tax payer instead of such large amounts being required to lay .for many months out in the hands of the County Treasurers, who are the collecting agents for the state; it simply means that the State's business is now taken care of with a less volume of money, just the same as it would be for a merchant to get along with less capital if he should con - vert from the credit system to the cash system. The old rule of forty 913-14 1,345.912.83 1,697,247.02 40,227.33 72,257.02 7,648.36 915-16 6.171.89

STATE TREASURER 1 years has been done away with, and the state is now able to do business on a cash basis, and will be able to continue on this basis unless the State Board of Assessment should sometime make the levy too small to meet the appropriations of the legislatures. DEPOSITS IN BANKS. It has been the policy of the department to deposit all funds In banks of the state, as provided in Chapter 18, Section 8655, General Stat - utes of 1913, and to distribute the funds as much as possible so that all sections of the state might be treated impartially and irrespective of political affiliations of the banking institutions. Each National Bank has been required to deposit with the State Auditor security as required by law; deposits in State Banks are protected by the State Guaranty Fund. At the present time th<: state has funds deposited in four hundred and :iv,' National and State Banks. 1 have received three per cent on all deposits on daily balances and from this source $72,257.02 has been turn - ed into the general fund of the Treasury. At the present time, the naming of the depository banks and the distribution of the funds among the same, is left entirely with the pleasure of the Treasurer. 1 think it would be much more satisfactory to the banks of the state, as well as to the treasurer of the state, if the law would require the State Treasurer to ask for, and receive bids from the various banks of the state, and that he would be required to at all times keep the funds on deposit with the banks which were willing to pay the largest rate of interest on the same. This would bring a better return of interest to the state from its deposits among the banks, and would fix a definite plan for the naming of depository banks and how much funds should be given them. I recommend the passage of some such law by the next legislature. I'SE OF CASH' FEES BY ANY DEPARTMENT IS AN ABUSED PRIV - ILEGE AND A WASTE OF PUBLIC FUNDS. The people of Nebraska have tried for over forty years to get away from the waste and abuse of giving to any public official or employee for himself or for others the use of the fees derived from his services or by his department. With the adoption of the State Constitution of 1875. the state's executive officers were denied the use of any more fees and in lieu thereof, were given a fixed salary. The Clerk of the Supreme Court. County Treasurers and other officers have been changed from fees to fix - ed salaries. The use of fees in many departments of the state govern - ment is being permitted by the legislature. In many instances, this privilege is being abused and more money is being used and spent than is necessary. The Legislature should abolish the use of any and all fees or cash funds: should direct their payment into the treasury and into the general fund, and should appropriate a fixed salary for each person em - ployed in the various departments and a fixed amount for the incidental expense of the various departments aside from salaries. In every in - stance, if there is a general need for a department or a board or officer.

6 RKPORT OF the Legislature should appropriate the necessary salaries and expense whether any fees, much or little, is derived for such services. RECEIPTS AND RECORDS. This department should be able to make such records as would show the identical corporation, firm or individual making payment to the state, either directly into the Treasury or through any department or institu - tion, together with the postoffice address, the amount paid, and for what purpose or under what law. The department is not able to make such a record because some of the other departments or institutions do not furn - ish us with such information, and the Treasurer is without authority to require such information. There should be a law giving the State Treas - urer sole authority and supervision over the collection of all funds through the various departments or institutions, with authority to ap - point one or more deputies in each department or institution to receive and receipt for moneys collected. In the present system there is no pos - itive check up, and there can be none. A law as suggested above, would make complete records with full information, and make possible the trac - ing of every dollar, and a complete audit of all funds received. FISCAL AGENCY. The Fiscai Agency is not 'properly a part of the duties of the State Treasurer. But it is properly a part of the various County Treasurers' duties. The State Treasurer is the custodian of state moneys, only. Fis - cal agency moneys are not State Funds, and are not protected to various subdivisions of the state by the State Treasurer's Bond. The several County Treasurers are the tax collectors of funds to pay all bonds and coupons issued within the state, and should be the paymaster. Their funds are protected by their bonds. The law should be amended to make them the Fiscal Agent, and their office the iplace of payment of all bonds Is - sued in their respective counties. It would keep the money in the county where it belongs till it is used, and would save duplication of work and expense. APPROPRIATIONS. If the Legislature will change the place of payment of all bonds, and coupons from the State Treasurer's office to the offices of the County Treasurers, who collect the taxes for their respective payment, the de - partment will be able to do the work with the present force, although the work in the department has been much heavier during this biennium than it ever was before. The heavier work is accounted for by the month - ly remittances from County Treasurers, and the increase of individual receipts through some of the departments. During the bienntum, the de - partment has issued 24,849 official receipts, as compared with 15,346 for the previous biennium, an increase of 9,503 receipts, or 62 per cent. If the plan of payment of the various bonds Issued within the state is left at the State Treasurer's office, the work of the office will Increase just the amount necessary to handle the payment of all bonds and coupons issued during the next two years. This will require the assistance of one

p STATE TREASURER 7 extra clerk. The department will need an additional appropriation (or incidental expenses of $500.00, because the appropriation of two years ago was not sufficient to meet all expenses to April 1, 1917. The office is in bad condition, and there is needed $500.00 to clean, paint and paper, and buy some carpet or rugs. The department needs the use of another adding and listing machine. Estimate for biennium is as follows: The records of the department are in splendid condition, for which much credit is due to the qualification and efficiency of the personnel of the office force. Individually, and as a whole, the force is not excelled by any other department or institution in the state. GEORGE E. HALL, State Treasurer.
